WITNESS:  Nobody is going to give you analogy A for your
particular field.  You got to find out different
elements from analogy from different fields all around
the world.  This is exactly what we did in Chevron
when I worked for them.
Last but not least, we have to control our

professional insight into problems we encounter.
We're not going to get 80, 85 per cent recovery when
the reservoir is heterogeneous, when there is water
influx, whether edge water or bottom water.  It
doesn't matter.
When water hits the gas, it's not like a piston
displacement.  It's a porous medium six water meanders
through gas and traps the gas and I'm going to show it
to you, sir.  A huge amount of gas can be trapped when
the reservoir influx.
1  Q. So this is a summary of what should have happened and
what didn't happen?
A. Now, we're moving to the next slide, which is the
fundamental principles of reservoir management.
CHAIRMAN:  We'll be discussing the guiding principles in
what we're doing.
We'll be discussing what happened in terms of
reservoir management of this field.
A. And I was able to see a document that Government of
India/DGH had regarding avoiding over-production,
preventing early water breakthrough and optimising
recovery.  It is realised, but can we practice these
things?
MR SALVE:  So now you are in India.  You got to love
elephant also.  In fact, my name is named after the
elephant God, Ganesha.
So we look at how do we balance ourselves as
a reservoir management manager:
"We have a big load to carry.  Do this weekly and
you will be able to extract more gas.  We all know
investment confidence is proportional to the certainty
of the outcome."
So investment decision in D1-D3 required is
special care.  We need to be cautious and judicious.
In our forecast of OGIP recovery factor, RF, reserves,
facilities design and reservoir management.
In Hindi, or Gujarati, we have a proverb "Hindi
spoken", translated in English "a cautious person is
always happy."
Then we look at exposure to risks can be optimised
through economic honesty in estimating OGIP and
reserves.
Maybe a cautious person would never go into
hydrocarbon recovery?
A. Sir, I am cautious person and I have made a very good
living in the hydrocarbon business, for the last
55 years.
CHAIRMAN:  But you're over there in Houston.  You can't
do all of the cases that come up, including in India,
and the contractor had very good technical advisory
people.  You say they made mistakes and that's what
we've got to focus on.
But amongst the many differences, that's the
nature of professionalism?
A. Absolutely.  Just like two doctors have slightly
different opinions regarding the same patient at times
and that is okay.
Technical sincerity regarding connectivity,
deliverability, delta "P", pressure drop, excessive
production rates.  These are what to focus on in
bringing the humility.
What I have learned is that more I study, more
I feel I know less about the subject.  Because things
are complicated and we have to realise respect the
force of nature.
So now we moving to risk and uncertainties.
Definition of risk, exposure to danger, but that can
be minimised through preventive measures.
These are the GIPIP of our industry.  Definition
of uncertainty, there are multiple outcomes.  Because
there is insufficient information.
We cannot eliminate the risk, but how we manage
the risk and reduce the uncertainty is very important.
In our business, sir, there is no silver bullet, but
E&P industry continues to flourish.
Today US is producing 13.3 million barrels of oil
per day.  Production in the US is higher than ever
been before.  So this industry is flourishing.  We
just have to be careful and manage the projects
appropriately.
I always believe defence wins the championship.
So that's the philosophy I have always followed.
CHAIRMAN:  So that's the philosophy I have always
followed.
enough about our reservoir and is listed in this
particular slide in a sequential way what we could do
to make a project like this successful.
I'm not going to glance through them.  They are
described in a sequential phase.
Q. Kindly look at this item 3, "EWT", extended well test,
"EPT", early production test, and producing a few
wells very fast, producing a few wells early on for
a limited time and creating the data that you create
in the production phase you create that data early on.
You collect that data early on?
A. And you calibrate your reservoir model to make
a forecast.  Then this is what we followed exactly in
2004 in the Jansz and Sanholo fields in the deep water
of Gulf of Mexico.
I'm very proud to tell you, sir, that was a very
difficult formation called Wilcox formation.  The net
to gross ratio in that field is even more complicated
than D1-D3.
So I didn't know how to make a production forecast
just using simulation and material balancing equation.
SIR BERNARD RIX:  So what we had to do?
A. Is do early production test.  Because production test
is your gold standard for these kind of projects.
Q. Geological means and geophysical means alone.
It has to be holistic.  It has to be integrated?
A. So now we move to the guiding principles of GIPIP and
UK has done a great job in providing a good field
development planning guidelines that you see the
reference here.  Once again, EWT is extended well test
that you produce the well for an extended time period.
Early test is very similar and you produce the
well as early as possible and collecting the data.
The purpose of EWT and/or ep T is to obtain
essential field and then reservoir information and
follow a phased development approach by producing and
production, in a phased development approach is what
we need to follow.
The key fact, features of FDP also and will be an
explanation of the commitments that the licensees are
making regarding facilities, number of wells, to bring
forward a sound development.
(Short break)
CHAIRMAN:  The operator did not estimate reserves
properly.
A. There was improper characterisation of reservoir.
Reservoir simulation was not used effectively,
sensitivity analysis were not performed appropriately.
The drive mechanisms were not simulated effectively.
Any time an operator doesn't follow the process,
we get burned.  If we follow the process, still there
is no 100 per cent guarantee, but the chance of
success is very high -- very high.
Q. So this is coming out of directly PRMS 2007 is what
often happens, and we had in D1-D3, such as those
involving water influx we had water influx.
So we had multi-phase behaviour:
"We have a multi-layered system and then it's like
this and it means this means the reservoir is not like
a sand box."
A. The reservoir has many layers like a layered cake and
each layer has sometimes different permeabilities.  So
the gas and water phases flow at different velocities
in these layers.
5  Q. So there is no way you can stop the water.  So
overproducing a given field at a high rate in
a multi-layered reservoir, come on, it's not possible..
Also the predictive models are most reliable in
estimating recoverable reserves when there is enough
production historical data, which wasn't here present.
So can't rely on models only.  You got to be
cautious.  You got to be ready?
A. For these kind of scenarios.  If we are not careful,
we get burned.
JUSTICE KHARE:  That's exactly what happens.
A. Guiding principles for GIPIP models must match
reality.  Validate the model.  Don't just model it.
Because if the models are not validated, they are not
useful.  They're only a scientific tool.  How do we
use that scientific tool is also very important.
In IDL situation, if the reservoir was completely
homogeneous in the D1-D3 field, if all the sands
behave the same way, if they were continuous, if they
were isotropic, that means permeabilities in different
directions are the same and if there is sufficient
high quality pressure data is available, just having
the pressure data from the MDT is not that useful for
material balance methodology.
If we rely on material balance only, we're going
to get surprises.  This is what we got to focus on.
The predictive models are most reliable in estimating
recoverable quantities when there is sufficient
production history to validate the model.  If we don't
have this, we got difficulties.
Moving now onto reserves.  What we see here on
this graph on the right side is the reserves value on
the vertical axis and they are proved reserves, P1,
with more than 90 per cent confidence.  Equal to or
more than 90 per cent confidence.
Horizontal axis gives different estimates which
are available.
These are by different reports, GCA, D&M, PGS, RIL
and different sized entities have come up with
different estimates of P1 reserves.
If you look at the values until 2006, until 2007,
except for one value, where would be our P1 reserves
estimates from this data?  Can anybody guess?
My honourable counsel, can you guess the values
that we would get?
You know, anybody can guess the value is going to
be 7 or 8.  No, that's an outlier.  The value is going
to be around 3 plus/minus -- 3.5.
Well, in this field, we've produced 2.3.
7  Q. That's what you're looking for.
A. P1 reserves, especially in the US, Security and
Exchange Commission goes after you in your P1 reserves
are off.  Look at what happened to Shell in 2004.
CHAIRMAN:  I saw that mentioned in a footnote at some
stage I'd be interested to know?
A. Absolutely, sir.  Absolutely, sir.
P1 reserves, it is really like in the US, when
I worked in the reserves, evaluation -- by the way,
for Chevron I worked 15 years in the reserves
evaluation for all over the world.
CHAIRMAN:  Yes, but you're one person, a very skilled and
expert person.  There are lots of people with
expertise and they have to also be used in faraway
countries.  I mean, this is a worldwide thing.
A. Absolutely.  Thank you, sir.
So P1 reserves we have to be very accurate.
P2 frankly speaking, Security and Exchange
Commission in the US.
Does not even pay attention to.  They're not going
to check you on that.  But on P1 if you're wrong, they
are going to take care of us.  So we got to be just
right in P1.
So now let's move to project management process,
PMP, to create maximum value.
You may recall this picture comes from WRMP.  This
picture is used by Chevron, in the Gorgon field, in
the Jansz field of the gas production.
What this picture shows is that it's not possible
to find the value on the vertical axis on the
horizontal, says from phase 1 to phase 5.  Just
like this.
Q. What it shows is that if you define the project

regarding recovery factor calculation.
This is a contract.  This is an agreement.  This

A. This is the LOI on which he's writing number 1.
Number 2, this could be part of the negotiations
which were superseded later on, because why do you

Q. If you just allow me, please, I will continue based on
the FIDIC that the client has a right to extend
the DLP.
However, in your case, basically you said no, we
have to leave, and this is -- there is no extension
for DLP?
A. It's up to you.
PROF THAKUR:  I have another question for you, please.
The NCR, you have stated that this clause ^ closed
The NCR, you have stated that this closed from
where did you conclude that the NCR is closed?
A. Because the subcontractor's people then they came
along and also when they visited the site, they did
everything and submitted a report in writing to the
respondent and all the details are given in my report.
Q. This is basically -- it should be confirmed by the
respondent.  The recipient of this NCR?
MR SALVE:  After inspection, normally they should submit
their acceptance of the work unless if you have
provided the work up to the condition and standard you
should come back and claim that the respondent
actually is not accepting the NCR for no reason,
without any grounds.  Did you do that?
A. I think Mr Ashraf, when the site is handed over and
during the DLP period, any NCRs are there, there is no
one at the site except watchmen and he will open.
We will do the work and he will sign that we had
come and done the work.
MR DAYAL:  Do you agree with me that the NCR should be
accepted actually, Mr Sprange, and also that it must
be approved by the respondent?
A. Accepted, but who will accept it?  Because there's no
one from their side.
6  Q. I don't understand.  What do you mean no one from the
that using an early production system here, they were

A. The thing is these documents are all referring to

continuity.
16 Q. And they mention in their paper it should be noted
A. The NCRs which we are referrring with reference to

Q. It's called the AC solar system.
A. AC solar system is what you're -- (overspeaking) --
Q. Yes, it's the AC solar system they installed last

A. But the very simple reason the design was not capacity
done some.
and that is proven by the very fact that your people
(The hearing adjourned until 10 am on the following day)
I N D E X
replaced this machinery of our capacity.  So you tell

expect us to repair it?
Because we attended the call, but still the
capacity was less.  Therefore, the equipment would not

10 Q. Did you notify at any point that the capacity is not
sufficient of the design?
A. The inspection report is wrong.  The consultant has
given a false inspection report?  Is that what you're
saying?
Q. The consultant made a comment on this.
A. The consultant --
12 Q. The consultant has put the comments?
A. No, I'm referring to -- (overspeaking) --
Q. You mean the AC?
A. The inspection report which is replacing the
equipment.
A. Handling charge, not 15 per cent.  15 per cent is
profit.
Would you agree that there could be, but less?
A. Yes.
MR SPRANGE:  If we look at paragraph 60, you say:
"Any amount by the respondent to carry out any
third-party repairs beyond liability period shall be
at the respondent risk and cost."
A. Yes.
MR SPRANGE:  And that is on the basis that claimant has
all the problems beyond DLP.
A. Yes.
MR SPRANGE:  And I wanted to ask you, are you basing your
statement that the claimant has attended the problems
beyond DLP on the basis of the letters on the record
and, for example, exhibit 3?
A. He has the latest documents that are going to say --
they are all dated January 2022, number 1.
Waited for the DLP to be finished, which means
he's acknowledging that DLP got finished.
MR SPRANGE:  In paragraph 64 you say:
"The claimant has rectified all the NCRs and the
respondents agree they found it all to be incorrect."
On what basis do you reach that conclusion,
Mr Raji?
A. Yes, well -- we have given the supporting documents
folders which show that how it was attended.
Therefore what will be will be for those all documents
to begin with those NCRs.
MR SPRANGE:  Okay.
A. Of course if you need further information --
MR SPRANGE:  Yeah.  NCR attendance by the claimant.
Before we go to the extension of time and
prolongation cost, let me see if I can pull this all
together.
This is the respondent's expert report.  Do you
know this document?
Q. Yeah, this is basically the summary of -- have you
seen this document?
A. Yes, yes.
Q. I want just to ask whether you agree with this
document?  Have you seen this document?  It's
basically a comparison --
A. The headings are okay, but I don't agree with the
liquidated damages.  I don't agree with some of the
backcharges which are approved by the respondent.
Q. Yeah.  I would like to just put this one, because it's
the document that made the comparison which I find
quite practical.
So we've got the position of the claimant, the
position of the respondent, the claimants' expert
opinion and the respondent expert opinion.
Cross-examination by MR SPRANGE
MR SPRANGE:  We see the difference in positions?
A. Yeah.
Q. So for liquidated damages you don't agree and you
explain in your report that it should be back to back.
Could you explore a little bit?
A. Yes.  Two things.  Number 1, only the place where
liquidated damages is mentioned is -- I'll just take
out the document and show you where I'm referring to.
It is article 7 of the subcontract, where it
mentions the liquidated damages.
I will, if I may, read it to you:
"The second party shall stick together with the
first party's documentation and then over the time of
depletion, if the progress of the subcontract is
delayed, the first party shall have right to
AED 50,000 per calendar day for a maximum of
10 per cent of the final subcontract amount."
First of all, there are two problems with this
sentence.  It says "if the progress is delayed".  It
doesn't say that completion is delayed.
And progress delay any liquidated damages, let's
say that these are liquidated damages.  Then this
liquidated damages have to be proven, because these
are not pre agreed to, this thing, this 50,000 per
day.  How they suffered by delaying the progress?
Because they also delayed the progress by agreement
with the client.
The second thing is that there is no other mention
of liquidated damages anywhere because it just then
goes to say that penalty is back to back.  Now,
penalty and liquidated damages in UAE courts are
treated as interchangeable.
Plus there is something whatsoever in that.  So
that means that when there is no mention, the intent
is that this is a penalty.  Even respondent himself
one of his letters has mentioned that we'll be
charging a penalty of 50,000, which are liquidated
damages as per clause 7.
So even he's not sure that what is it, liquidated
damages or penalty.
Now, according to me, you cannot have both penalty
and liquidated damages, one.
Second thing is it is all back to back.  In what
way the respondent would refer to any penalty on
liquidated damages by the main contract.
MR SPRANGE:  Thank you.  If we continue looking at this
table quickly, so we spoke about the liquidated
damages.  We spoke about the handling charges?
A. Yes.
Q. We speak about the NCR.  This one is item 17 on page 3
of the document on the screen.
A. After defects liability.
Q. It's the deduction:
"Due to claimants' failure or rectifying BTU meter
leakage."
What was your conclusion on this one?
A. This one, deduction is after the defects liability
period.
Q. Okay.  The cost of respondent's staff overstaying
after claimant left the site during DLP, this one you
also reason, number 1, let us say that in case if the
claimant delays the project, what options does the
respondent have?  He can either terminate the
subcontract or he can charge penalty or liquidated
damages as per the contract.  This is one.
But whereas the overstaying is for what?
Overstaying he has not now, for example, there are
three, four claims of overstaying.  One is because of
DEWA, the respondent expert has put charges as staying
after the handover, because he then says that to stay
and he says 30 per cent amount is to be given for
solar as well as AC.
Now, the only these two were outstanding issues
and for which seven workers, two supervisors and one
project manager they stayed for seven months and
30 per cent of their time they devote in doing what?
Because anyway, the equipment was replaced.
MR SPRANGE:  Okay.
CHAIRMAN:  Now, as we move to the extension of time and
prolongation cost, so you in your report you state
that the extension of time is of 344 days, because you
conclude that there were 221 concurrent delays, so the
costs are 2,490,000?
A. Extension of time is not that.  Extension of time is
564 days, out of which 21 is the concurrent delay I
was referring to earlier.
Q. Let me just go back.
So I think it's by the end.  So I wanted to ask
you on the delay events, for example, because what you
say at the end of each delay, is that what -- so if we
go delay event number 1, so what I wanted is to
explain to you how, for example, delay event number 1
impacted the project and the critical path to the
extent that it become compensible.
The reason being that we know that the completion
date was supposed to be December 2018?
A. Yes.
Q. And the 12-month prolongation started in
February 2019, which was after the initial completion
date was completed.  So there was already a delay in
for the project.  So I want you to explain to me,
please, how that extension of 12 months had, you know,
impacted the critical path?
A. Actually, this to be explained to you by the other
witness.  The reason is you have to put -- as you can
see here, I have put a fragnet.  I impact any
programme with a fragnet.
One is your extension, because there are event
which are over-lapping and which are overflowing the
works.
SIR BERNARD RIX:  So for example, in delay event number
2, you say:
"This event by itself does not entitle the
claimant to an extension of time as this event does
not affect the critical path.  However, as a direct
consequence of this on the roof, it has led to an
extended delay."
A. Yes.

(Short break)
MR SPRANGE:  It's not on the accurate, but it's kind of
prolonged period.  So what is exactly the reasoning
and the conclusion?
A. You see, in order to impact the programme, the event
has to impact the critical path.  The critical path
means without that it cannot go ahead.
Now, here this did not impact the critical path to
the full extent.  The chiller installation, testing
HVAC, handover all these things were not impacted
because overall delay was less, impacted comes only
16 days and that is the impact I have taken into
account on this.
Q. Here, for example you, didn't count the whole seven
days as delay?
A. I have marked it as a delay, but it is not on the
critical path.  I have not taken it as an impact.
Q. I think that's it for you, Mr Ajeet.  I think that's
it.  Thank you so much.  Let me just stop sharing.
Thank you very much for giving your evidence.
A. If I may just say something?
Some of the sentences are especially -- I have
spent 35 years on the site.  So my way of talking is
a little bit rough.  I'm not exactly a model of
politeness, so --
Q. No, you have been very polite and cordial.  Thank you
for your evidence and your experience is highlighted
in your report which I read.  Thank you very much.
A. God bless.
CHAIRMAN:  We are running very late, gentlemen.
I think, you know, what do the parties need in
terms of cross-examining the witnesses?  There's no
problem.  We just wanted to draw your attention that
it's 2.30.  We are running almost two hours late --
actually, not two hours late.  One hour late.
Let's have a 10-minute break and then resume at
2.40.  Is that okay?  Or you prefer to continue?
MS BAJAJ:  15 minutes, if it doesn't bother anyone.
CHAIRMAN:  It's okay for you?
MR SPRANGE:  I'm good with that.  15 minutes.  Thank you
very much.
We want to make sure of what Mr Ram will be giving
evidence on is the fact witness that you witness
statement that you wrote, that is dated 29 May 2023,
is that correct?
WITNESS:  Yes, correct.
CHAIRMAN:  Do you have it in front of you, not annotated
with just like a clean version of it?
WITNESS:  I have it, yes.
CHAIRMAN:  Okay.  Perfect.  So that's your evidence and
Mr San will start cross-examination.
Cross-examination by MR SPRANGE
MR SPRANGE:  Good afternoon.
A. Good afternoon.
Q. So let's go to the main point.  You have said in the
first paragraph under the heading, "Early stages of
the project", this damage has been a problem from the
beginning.  They knew how many bank guarantee in this
contract and despite that mostly with the bank, but
they signed this subcontract from the bank guarantee
some time.  I just wanted to ask you what is ask you
to do with this?
A. On this issue they knew that they are not able to make
bank guarantee.  They have not read it in the banks.
Even as soon as we started this after three months,
Even as soon as we started this after three
months, they wanted to bring chiller to import it.
They give us a letter.
In that letter, they explain that they are
incapable with their bank of their LC.  They requested
an LC.  So if they are an honest subcontractor, they
should not come to this contract or at least they
should not promise me they did bank guarantee.  They
knew they cannot bring within the guarantee period.
But they will rarely give you a cheque, security, we
will bring bank guarantee later.  It's even now they
did to me.  I consider they are dishonest from the
beginning.
28 Q. So they substituted performance security cheque
instead of a bank guarantee, right?
A. They didn't substitute.  They say temporary we give
you this cheque, considering the bank guarantee.
Whenever we push them, they said, "Wait, wait".
Q. But as we have on the record that the performance
security cheque is with you and not encashed it.
Correct?
A. Yes, yes.  I didn't want to make trouble for them.
I didn't do.
30 Q. Already they have substituted with the performance
security cheque and plus 10 per cent retention fee
also you have claimed because of that, right?
A. Yes.
Q. How has it prejudiced your client or you to set up
a bank guarantee they are giving you a performance
security cheque plus 10 per cent retention.  How does
it prejudice your case?
A. Look, this company they said we are paying you a bank
guarantee until then.  We did not take 10 per cent of
this or any amount until we bring this bank guarantee
to you.  But you know what will happen?
First of all, take a lot of times has no value
because it is going to bonds bank guarantees
100 per cent guarantee.
Another one.  Any deduction you do 10 per cent for
example instead of performance you deduct that, in the
every stage of the project it is a part of the total.
The bank guarantee is the total amount of the
project -- 10 per cent, not total.  But any payment
received is the lesser amount, so this is also to the
main contractor.
For example, if they have done 20 per cent, this
will be 2 per cent of the total project deduction.
But if they have given bank guarantee, it is exactly
10 per cent of the total guarantee by the bank.  So
this is the help I have accepted.  This one is with
them.
Q. So could you have encashed the performance security
cheque?  Why didn't you do it?
A. I didn't want to harm them.
33 Q. Why?
A. If they were not their enemy.  I'm not their enemy.
I consider their contractor.  They requested my help.
I give them a chance.  I gave them a chance.
Q. How long do you give a chance for?  This project
started on 27 October.  The agreement was signed on
27 October 2017.  They were supposed to give the bank
guarantee at the initial stage only.  You kept on
supplying all the time with them.  What do you mean to
say they just unhappy you still continue with them?
A. Look, if you see what other thing I have done for
them, I tell that -- something has happened to this
screen now.  I don't see you.
Okay.  I can tell you that the bank exist for more
than 30 years.  No money for the construction site.
I never went to their premises.  But a lot of time
because of the subcontractor I went to site to give
them a chance.  Until the day that we realise they are
completely incapable and we terminated them.
My limit of patience, then one day we said enough.
Then we sent to them a termination letter.  After
that, this is another thing that I complain about,
this event what you have written as lawyer you listen
to them and they say as a witness.  You didn't write
the truth.  You have written that respondent realised
that the termination letter is not legal and they just
simply need the wrong letter.  No.
35 Q. Are you suggesting that we have not credited the
correct thing?  Is that what you are saying?
A. Yes, yes, yes.  I can prove to you that this is what
is going -- (overspeaking) -- you are not reading in
the letter properly.  You now --
Q. Mr Ram, you may get into that aspect here.
(The hearing adjourned until 9.30 am on the following day)
